column1: But they also saddled governments with large deficits, which soon came to be viewed as an obstacle to recovery – the opposite of what Keynes taught.
column2: 但也让政府背上了巨大的赤字，很快这就被视为复苏的障碍 — — 这与凯恩斯的教义背道而驰。

column1: With unemployment still high, governments returned to pre-Keynesian orthodoxy, cutting spending to reduce their deficits – and undercutting economic recovery in the process.
column2: 在失业率仍然高企的情况下，政府回归前凯恩斯时代的正统，削减支出以降低赤字 — — 也在此过程中扼杀了经济复苏。

column1: There are three main reasons for this regression.
column2: 这一倒退主要原因有三。

column1: First, the belief in the labor-market-clearing power of prices in a capitalist economy was never wholly overturned.
column2: 首先，在资本主义经济中，对价格的劳动力市场出清力的信念从未被完全颠覆。

column1: So most economists came to view persistent unemployment as an extraordinary circumstance that arises only when things go terribly wrong, certainly not the normal state of market economies. The rejection of Keynes’ notion of radical uncertainty lay at the heart of this reversion to pre-Keynesian thinking.
column2: 因此，大部分经济学家将持续失业视为反常情况，只有在存在大问题时才会出现，绝非市场经济的常态。

column1: Second, post-war Keynesian “demand-management” policies, credited with having produced the long post-1945 boom, ran into inflationary trouble at the end of the 1960s.
column2: 其次，战后凯恩斯主义“需求管理”政策因为带来了1945年后的长时间繁荣而声名大振，但在20世纪60年代末陷入了通胀危机。

column1: Alert to a worsening tradeoff between inflation and unemployment, Keynesian policymakers tried to sustain the boom through incomes policy – controlling wage costs by concluding national agreements with trade unions.
column2: 受日益恶化的通胀和失业权衡的警示，凯恩斯主义决策者试图通过收入政策维持繁荣 — — 通过国家与工会的协议控制工资成本。

column1: Income policy was tried in many countries from the 1960s to the end of the 1970s.
column2: 20世纪60年代至70年代末，许多国家尝试了收入政策。

column1: At best, there were temporary successes, but the policies always broke down.
column2: 它们充其量只是起到了暂时的效果，最后无一例外地失败了。

column1: Milton Friedman provided a reason that jibed with growing disenchantment with wage and price controls, and that reasserted the pre-Keynesian view of how market economies work.
column2: 米尔顿·弗里德曼（Milton Friedman）解释了为何工资和价格控��日渐走下神坛，以及前凯恩斯时代的市场经济运行观点重新得势。

column1: Inflation, Friedman said, resulted from attempts by Keynesian governments to force down unemployment below its “natural” rate.
column2: 弗里德曼说，凯恩斯主义政府迫使失业下降到“自然”率之下导致了通货膨胀。

column1: The key to regaining stable prices was to abandon the full-employment commitment, emasculate the trade unions, and deregulate the financial system.
column2: 重新实现价格稳定的关键是抛弃充分就业承诺，削弱工会，减少对金融体系的监管。

column1: And so the old orthodoxy was reborn.
column2: 旧正统由此重生。

column1: The full-employment target was replaced by an inflation target, and unemployment was left to find its “natural” rate, whatever that was.
column2: 充分就业目标被通胀目标取代，失业被放任寻找其“自然”率（不论为何 ） 。

column1: It was with this defective navigational equipment that politicians sailed full steam ahead into the icebergs of 2008.
column2: 政客们就是凭借这一有缺陷的导航设备开足马力撞上了2008年的冰山。

column1: The final reason for Keynesianism’s fall from grace was the rightward ideological shift that began with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and US President Ronald Reagan.
column2: 凯恩斯主义失势的最后一个原因是始于英国首相撒切尔夫人和美国总统里根的意识形态右倾。

column1: The shift was due less to rejection of Keynesian policy than to hostility toward the enlarged state that emerged after World War II.
column2: 这一转变与其说是因为拒绝凯恩斯政策，不如说是因为对二战后出现的国家扩大的不满。

column1: Keynesian fiscal policy was caught in the crossfire, with many on the right condemning it as a manifestation of “excessive” government intervention in the economy.
column2: 凯恩斯主义财政政策成为众矢之的，许多右翼人士抨击它代表政府对经济的“过度”干预。

column1: Two final reflections suggest a renewed, if more modest, role for Keynesian economics.
column2: 两个最后的沉思暗示了凯恩斯主义的一个新生的、更加现代的角色。

column1: An even bigger shock to the pre-2008 orthodoxy than the collapse itself was the revelation of the corrupt power of the financial system and the extent to which post-crash governments had allowed their policies to be scripted by the bankers.
column2: 对2008年前正统的一个更大的冲击（比2008年崩溃还要大）是金融体系的腐败权力被曝光，人们看到崩溃后的政府是如何放任政策被银行家把持的。

column1: To control financial markets in the interests of full employment and social justice lies squarely in the Keynesian tradition.
column2: 为了充分就业和社会正义控制金融市场是凯恩斯主义的明确传统。

column1: Second, for new generations of students, Keynes’s relevance may lie less in his specific remedies for unemployment than in his criticism of his profession for modeling on the basis of unreal assumptions.
column2: 其次，对新一代学生来说，凯恩斯的重要性与其说在于他所提出的针对失业的具体办法，不如说在于他对经济学所提出的批评 — — 基于不现实的假设建立模型。

column1: Students of economics eager to escape from the skeletal world of optimizing agents into one of fully-rounded humans, set in their histories, cultures, and institutions will find Keynes’s economics inherently sympathetic.
column2: 经济学学生急切地渴望杯托优化行为人的抽象世界，进入丰满的人类世界，考虑历史、文化和制度，他们将发现凯恩斯经济学具有内在的共鸣。

column1: That is why I expect Keynes to be a living presence 20 years from now, on the centenary of the General Theory, and well beyond.
column2: 正因如此，我认为，直到20年后通论100周年及其后相当长一段时间，凯恩斯主义都将是活跃的存在。

column1: Keynes versus the Classics: Round Two
column2: 凯恩斯主义对经典主义：第二轮

column1: LONDON – The economist John Maynard Keynes wrote The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money (1936) to “bring to an issue the deep divergences of opinion between fellow economists which have for the time being almost destroyed the practical influence of economic theory…” Seventy years later, heavyweight economists are still at each other’s throats, in terms almost unchanged from the 1930’s.
column2: 伦敦 — —

column1: The latest slugfest features New Keynesian champion Paul Krugman of Princeton University and New Classical champion John Cochrane of the University of Chicago. Krugman recently published a newspaper article entitled “How Did Economists Get It So Wrong?”
column2: 经济学家凯恩斯在《就业，投资和金钱的基本理论 》 （ 1936年版）一书中写道 ： “ 长期以来一直存在的经济学家在观点上的壁垒鲜明的对立几乎摧毁了经济理论对现实的影响力 。 。 。 ”

column1: There was nothing in mainstream economics, Krugman wrote, “suggesting the possibility of the kind of collapse that happened last year.”
column2: 70年后的今天，各派重量级的经济学家相互之间依然争斗得你死我活，这和1930年代几乎没什么两样。

column1: The reason was that “economists, as a group, mistook beauty, clad in impressive-looking math, for truth.” They purveyed an “idealized vision of an economy in which rational individuals interact in perfect markets.”
column2: 打得最为激烈的两派代表人物如下：一方是新凯恩斯主义的领军人，普林斯顿大学的保罗·克鲁格曼，一方是新古典主义的首领，芝加哥大学的约翰·科克伦。

column1: Unfortunately “this sanitized vision of the economy led most economists to ignore all the things that could go wrong.”
column2: 克鲁格曼近期在报纸上发表了标题为《经济学家这么错得如此离谱？

column1: So now economists will have to accept “the importance of irrational and often unpredictable behavior, face up to the often idiosyncratic imperfections of markets and accept that an elegant economic ‘theory of everything’ is a long way off.”
column2: 》一文。 “在主流经济学中没有这样的说法 ” ， 克鲁格曼写道 ： “ 可以推论出去年那场经济大崩盘会爆发的可能性 。 ”

column1: Krugman’s heavy pounding of Chicago School economics goaded Cochrane, a professor of finance, into some bad-tempered counter-punching on the university’s Web site, much of which consisted of a personal attack on Krugman’s scientific integrity.
column2: 原因在于 ： “ 经济学家，成为了这么一种团体，他们用具有迷惑力的数学来包装自己，给我们一个美丽的错觉，让我们看不清事情的本质 。 ” 同时，他们提供一个“理想化的经济模型，即市场是完美的，每个参与者都是理性的 。 ”

column1: When he gets around to economics, Cochrane aims his blows at two points: Krugman’s attack on the “efficient market theory” and his advocacy of “fiscal stimulus” for depressed economies.
column2: “不幸的是 ” ， 这种经过简单化的经济模式使得我们绝大多数经济学家忽视了一些要素，从而导致他们出错 。 ” 于是，现在的经济学家将会不得不知晓“非理性行为，经常发生的不可预测行为的重要性。
明白市场常常是带有某种不完美性，他们开始承认没有一种所谓放之四海皆有效的经济理论 。 ”

column1: Cochrane accuses Krugman of misleading his readers about the efficient market theory, which asserts that, given the available information, financial markets always get asset prices right.
column2: 克鲁格曼不断抨击芝加哥学派的经济学家“愤怒”的科克伦，科克伦是经济学教授，他在自己任教大学网站上不断地对克鲁格曼提出挑战，甚至质疑他的学术操守。

column1: Rather than defend that theory, Cochrane admits that “asset prices move more than reasonable expectations of future cash flows.” Unfortunately, “no theory is particularly good at that right now.”
column2: 在经济学领域方面，科克伦主要攻击两点：克鲁格曼对“有效市场理论”的抨击，以及他大力提倡的在经济萧条时期的政府“财政刺激”方案。

column1: But it’s theoretical nihilism, Cochrane argues, to ascribe these excessive fluctuations to “irrationality” as Krugman does.
column2: 科克伦指责克鲁格曼在有效市场理论的问题上误导读者。

column1: What Krugman is really after (“though he can’t quite come out and say this”) is for the government to “take charge of the allocation of capital.”
column2: 所谓有效市场理论是指，在信息充分的前提下，金融市场中订出的资产价格一向是合理的。

column1: And the one thing we do know is that however badly asset markets behave, government control “has always been much worse.”
column2: 科克伦并没有为这个理论辩护，他承认“资产价格比未来预期的合理现金流走得要远 ” 。 不幸的是 ， “ 目前并没有特别好的理论出现 。 ”

column1: Cochrane’s heaviest punching is reserved for Krugman’s support for President Barack Obama’s fiscal stimulus.
column2: 但科克伦也指出，这也是一种理论的虚无主义，不能将所有这些价格过度波动都归咎于克鲁格曼所认为的“非理性 ” 。

column1: He invokes the hoary old “Ricardian equivalence theorem,” revived by the Harvard economist Robert Barro, according to whom “debt-financed spending can’t have any effect, because people, seeing the higher future taxes that must pay off the debt, will simply save more.
column2: 克鲁格曼真正的目的（当然他不能明着说）是让政府“接管所有的资本 ” 。

column1: They will buy the new government debt and leave all spending decisions unaltered.”
column2: 但有一件事情我们是清楚的，那就是虽然资产市场表现糟糕，但政府的接管只能会把问题弄得更糟。

column1: In short, Krugman “has absolutely no idea about what caused the crash, what policies might have prevented it, and what policies we should adopt going forward” – except that the government should now spend money like a drunken sailor.
column2: 最令科克伦所诟病的是克鲁格曼对奥巴马总统所采取财政刺激方案的支持。 他引用由哈佛经济学家罗伯特·巴罗翻出来的过时的“李嘉图的等价定理”来说明 ， “ 负债救助不会生效，因为人们会预期到现在政府债务会导致未来的税收增加，于是他们就不会存钱。

column1: Far from having too much math, economists need more, in order to “keep the logic straight.”
column2: 反而会购买政府新发行的债券，从而使得政府的救助政策失灵 。 ”

column1: On the stimulus, though, Krugman achieves a knock-out punch. The view that extra government spending “crowds out” an equal amount of private spending, so that its net stimulus effect is zero, would be true only if the economy were at full employment.
column2: 简而言之，克鲁格曼在“经济崩盘的原因，如何防止危机再次发生，以及我们在此问题上能吸取什么教训”等问题上，没有任何贡献。

column1: Indeed, the Chicago School tacitly assumes that economies are always at full employment.
column2: — — 除了政府应该不断地花钱以外，就像一��醉酒的水手行为没什么两样。

column1: They are unfazed by the fact that America’s economy has shrunk by 4% in the last year and that over 6 million people have been added to the unemployment rolls.
column2: 对经济学家来说，目前的数学模型不是太多，而是需要更多才能使得“问题的解决更加有逻辑性 ” 。

column1: To Chicago economists, an increase in the number of idle workers represents a voluntary choice for leisure.
column2: 在经济刺激问题上，克鲁格曼获得了全胜。

column1: In a concession to commonsense, they concede that people may make mistakes and, to that extent, a stimulus may be beneficial.
column2: 有一种观点认为，政府的救助资金会排挤私人投资，救助的效果为零。 不过这种理论假设的前提条件是就业情况十分充分。

column1: But they insist that the only stimulus that will work is printing money.
column2: 实际上，芝加哥学派理论狡猾地将假设的前提设定为就业一直是保持良好的。

column1: This will drive down interest rates and lead to an economic rebound.
column2: 而去年美国经济下滑了4 % ， 600万人因此而失业，对于如此现状，他们却装作没看到。

column1: Against this view, Keynes pointed out that interest-rate reductions may not do the job, because at zero or near-zero rates investors hoard cash rather than lend it out.
column2: 对于芝加哥学派的经济学家来说，失业率的上升代表人们自愿选择休假。

column1: Hence, as he put it in 1932, there may be “no escape from prolonged and perhaps interminable depression except by direct state intervention to promote and subsidize new investment” – which is what the Obama administration is rightly doing.
column2: 如果基于这种判断，那么政府的经济救助无异于错误地鼓励人们休假。 他们认为唯一有效的方法就是多印钞票，这会降低利率，经济从而得以复苏。

column1: On the question of what caused the crash, the debate is more even.
column2: 在谈到是什么导致市场崩盘这个问题上，双方打了个平手。

column1: Krugman is hampered by the fact that he attributes the crash to “irrationality,” which, as Cochrane points out, is no theory.
column2: 克鲁格曼认为“非理性”是元凶。 而科克伦认为根本就没什么理论。

column1: This is because Krugman refuses to take seriously Keynes’s crucial distinction between risk and uncertainty.
column2: 按照凯恩斯的说法，风险和不确定性有着严格的界限。

column1: In my view, Keynes’s major contribution to economic theory was to emphasize the “extreme precariousness of the basis of knowledge on which our estimates of prospective yield have to be made.”
column2: 而这也正是克鲁格曼不愿意承认的事情。 在我看来，凯恩斯对于经济学最大的贡献在于，强调了“我们所能考虑到的各种极端的偶然情况 。 ”

column1: The fact of their ignorance forces investors to fall back on certain conventions, of which the most important are that the present will continue into the future, that existing share prices sum up future prospects, and that if most people believe something, they must be right.
column2: 投资者往往有盲点，但最为重要的事情是对未来的预期，从现在的股价推算出未来的上升空间，如果绝大多数人都这么认为的话，他们就是对的。

column1: This makes for considerable stability in markets as long as the conventions hold .
column2: 只要这种势头一直如此，市场就会一直保持相对的稳定。

column1: But they are liable to being overturned suddenly in the face of passing bad news, because “there is no firm basis of conviction to hold them steady.”
column2: 一旦坏消息传播开来，上述情况就会突然完全转变。 因为“没有足够坚实的基础能保证市场的稳定 。 ”

column1: It’s like what happens in a crowded theater if someone shouts “Fire!”
column2: 就像在一个拥挤的剧场中，突然有人大喊一声“着火了 ！ ”

column1: Everyone rushes to get out.
column2: 每个人都想要逃生。

column1: This is not “irrational” behavior.
column2: 这并不是“非理性的”行为。

column1: It is reasonable behavior in the face of uncertainty.
column2: 而是面对不确定性的一种理性行为。

column1: In essence, this is what happened last autumn.
column2: 从本质上来说，去年秋天所发生事情就是这样。

column1: Chicago School economics has never been more vulnerable than it is today – and deservedly so.
column2: 芝加哥学派的经济学理论从来就没有这么不堪一击 — — 他们确实也应该这样。

column1: But the attack on it will never succeed unless policy Keynesians like Krugman are willing to work out the implications of irreducible uncertainty for economic theory.
column2: 如果克鲁格曼只是攻击他们，当然也不会得到人们的认可，除非他能提出自己在经济学领域中 对于不确定性作出的自己独到见解。

column1: The Keys to Universal Health Coverage
column2: 全民健康覆盖的关键

column1: DAR ES SALAAM – It has been three years since world leaders committed to one of the boldest goals ever set in global public health: achieving universal health coverage by 2030.
column2: 达累斯萨拉姆—三年前，世界领导人做出了全球公共卫生史上最宏大之一的目标承诺：到2030年实现全民健康覆盖。

column1: Achieving this objective will mean that every person in every community has access to affordable care, both to prevent them from falling ill and to treat them when they do.
column2: 实现这一目标将意味着所有社区的每一个人都能获得平价医疗，不管是预防疾病还是疾病治疗。

column1: The stakes are simply too high not to deliver on this promise.
column2: 如果不能兑现这一承诺，代价将极其昂贵。

column1: We cannot eradicate poverty, protect people from pandemics, advance gender equality, or achieve any of the other 2030 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) without accelerating progress toward universal health coverage.
column2: 如果我们不加快全民健康覆盖不乏，就无法消除贫困，无法保护人民不患传染病，无法推动性别平等，无法实现其他所有2030年可持续发展目标（SDG ） 。

column1: Fortunately, national leaders are starting to take concrete steps toward expanding access to health care.
column2: 幸运的是，国家领导人也开始采取切实措施扩大医疗普及。

column1: As I, along with many others, have come to realize, success depends on first overcoming one of the most significant challenges in health: overly fragmented approaches to delivering care.
column2: 我和其他许多人意识到，成功首先要求克服最重大的健康挑战之一：实现医疗的方针过于碎片化。

column1: Instead of treating one disease at a time, we need to establish systems in which people’s diverse health needs are treated side by side.
column2: 我们需要的不是一次治好一种病，而需要建立人民多样化的健康需求能得到一一满足的体系。

column1: Every woman should be able to turn to a trusted provider in her community to receive family planning services for herself, routine immunizations for her children, or diabetes treatments for an aging relative.
column2: 每一名妇女都应该能够求助受信任的社区卫生服务提供者获得生育规划、幼儿常规免疫以及老年亲属的糖尿病治疗。

column1: The best way for countries to achieve a more integrated approach is to strengthen primary care, which is most people’s first point of contact with the health system.
column2: 各国实现更为一体化的方针的最佳办法是强化初级医疗。 初级医疗是大部分人与卫生体系打交道的起点。

column1: Primary-care providers can address more than 80% of health needs.
column2: 初级医疗提供者可以解决80%以上的健康需要。

column1: And because primary care is delivered to rich and poor alike, it is the foundation of a fair and equitable society.
column2: 而由于初级医疗不论穷富都能获得，因此它也是公正平等的社会的基础。

column1: Having recognized these potential benefits, world leaders recently met at the Global Conference on Primary Health Care in Astana, Kazakhstan, to endorse a new declaration that commits them to strengthening primary-care systems within their respective countries.
column2: 认识到这些潜在的好处，世界领导人最近齐聚哈萨克斯坦阿斯塔纳参加全球初级医疗会议（ Global Conference on Primary Health Care ） ， 支持一项要求各国强化初级医疗制度的新宣言。

column1: But now the hard work begins.
column2: 但现在，艰苦的工作才刚开始。

column1: With national leaders considering how best to meet their new commitment, I would emphasize two factors that are integral to making progress.
column2: 在与各国领导人思考如何实现新承诺时，我强调两个对于取得进展至关重要的因素。

column1: First, we need to maintain the political will to strengthen primary care and achieve universal health coverage.
column2: 首先，我们需要保证强化初级医疗、实现全民健康覆盖的政治意愿。

column1: To that end, World Health Organization Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus recently called on heads of state and government to undertake concrete reforms in that direction starting this year.
column2: 在这方面，世界卫生组织总干事谭德塞（Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus）最近呼吁各国和政府首脑从今年开始沿着这一方向采取切实的改革。

column1: From my own experience as a former president of Tanzania, I know that persistent, firm, top-level leadership is necessary to move the complex machinery of government.
column2: 从我作为坦桑尼亚前总统的个人经验看，深知持续、坚实的顶层领导对于驱动复杂的政府机制是必不可少的。 因此。

column1: That is why I joined with the health advocacy organization Access Challenge to launch the “One by One: Target 2030” campaign on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly this year.
column2: 我加入了卫生支持组织普及挑战组织（Access Challenge ） ， 发起了今年联合国大会的非正式议程“一个接一个：目标2030 ” （ One by One: Target 2030）项目。

column1: As part of the campaign, I will be meeting with leaders throughout Africa to encourage them to take tangible steps toward strengthening primary care.
column2: 作为该项目的一部分，我将与全非洲的领导人会晤，鼓励他们为强化初级医疗制定具体的措施。

column1: The goal is to protect the basic right to health of every child, adolescent, mother, and family.
column2: 目标是保护每一位儿童、青少年、母亲和家庭的基本健康权。

column1: The second key to progress is improved data so that we can monitor what we have accomplished and what work remains to be done.
column2: 取得进步的第二个关键是改善数据，以便监控我们完成了哪些工作、还有哪些工作需要完成。

column1: Reliable data are needed to determine whether people are encountering financial or geographic obstacles to health care; whether care is being administered safely and effectively; and whether it is reaching the most marginalized groups in society.
column2: 确定人们在求医过程中是否遇到财务或地理方面的障碍、医疗服务是否安全有效、是否覆盖了社会中最边缘的群体，都需要可靠的数据。

column1: National leaders and public health officials need to know all of this and more in order to identify weaknesses in the primary-care system and target areas for improvement.
column2: 国家领导人和公共卫生官员需要了解所有这些，才能发现初级医疗体系的弱点，并定位改善领域。

column1: Data are also an important tool for health-care advocates and average citizens who want to track progress over time, hold leaders accountable, and demand the care they need and deserve.
column2: 医疗支持者和普通公民想要跟踪一段时间以来的进展、问责领导人、要求他们需要和赢得的开户，也需要数据。

column1: Yet too often, and despite its potential to drive improvement and foster accountability, data collection is treated as an afterthought.
column2: 但经常发生的情况是，尽管数据能够带来进步、形成问责，但数据收集工作并没有被列为重点。

column1: The Primary Health Care Performance Initiative is working to address precisely this issue.
column2: 初级医疗表现计划（Primary Health Care Performance Initiative，PHCPI）致力于解决这个问题。

column1: At the Global Conference on Primary Health Care, the PHCPI joined with several countries from around the world to launch a new tool to help policymakers and providers improve care.
column2: 在全球初级医疗会议上，PHCPI与来自全球的多个国家一起推出了新的工具帮助决策者和供应商改善看护。

column1: With Vital Signs Profiles, they can quickly access information on primary care that is both useful and easy to understand.
column2: 它们将利用生命体征情况（Vital Signs Profiles）迅速获得有用又容易理解的初级医疗信息。

column1: As I begin to reach out to African leaders one by one, I look forward to the day when we will have achieved universal health coverage for the world’s 7.7 billion people.
column2: 在我与非洲领导人一对一会晤时，我在想象有朝一日我们能够实现覆盖全世界77亿人的全民健康。

column1: With high-level political commitments and new tools for promoting access to care and fostering accountability, I am confident that we can make this ambitious vision a reality.
column2: 促进医疗普及、提高可问责性有高层政治意愿和新工具支持，我 有信心我们能够让这一宏大愿景转化为现实。

column1: How Can Countries Reduce Poverty Faster?
column2: 各国如何更快减贫？

column1: KUALA LUMPUR and MANCHESTER – Can the world end poverty by 2030, the target set by the United Nations Agenda for Sustainable Development?
column2: 吉隆坡和曼彻斯特—世界能够在2030年消灭贫困，实现这一联合国可持续发展目标所制定的目标吗？

column1: The UN General Assembly recently reaffirmed this deadline but conceded that meeting it will require “accelerating global actions” to tackle poverty’s causes.
column2: 联合国大会最近重申了这一时限，但承认，实现这一目标需要“加快全球行动”解决贫困的根源。

column1: As the international community explores new solutions, lessons from the past could be instructive.
column2: 在国际社会探索新方案的时候，历史教训很有指导意义。

column1: Poverty reduction has been central to development policy for decades.
column2: 几十年来，减贫一直是发展政策的核心。

column1: During the 15 years of the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), the predecessor to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the percentage of people living in poverty – defined as less than $1.90 a day – declined significantly, from nearly 27% in 2000, when the MDGs began, to about 9% in 2017.
column2: 在千年发展目标（MDG）的15年中，生活在贫苦中的人口 — — 每天生活费低于1.90美元 — — 比例大幅下将，从MDG启动的第一年2000年的近27 % ， 下降到2017年的约 9 % 。 MDG是可持续发展目标（SDG）的前身。

column1: At first glance, the rate of poverty reduction in the first few years of the SDGs has also been impressive.
column2: 乍一看，SDG最初几年的减贫速度也令人印象深刻。

column1: Between January 2016 and June 2018, an estimated 83 million people were lifted out of extreme poverty.
column2: 2016年1月至2018年6月期间，据估计有8,300万人摆脱了极端贫困。

column1: And yet, to remain on track to meet the 2030 target date, about 120 million people should have escaped poverty during that period.
column2: 但是，要保持这一势头，在2030年实现目标，还需要让大约1.2亿人摆脱极端贫困。

column1: Despite the welcome gains, the pace of progress has been less than satisfactory.
column2: 尽管进展令人欣喜，但进展的速度差强人意。

column1: In a recent paper co-authored for the journal World Development, we examined what factors drive successful poverty reduction.
column2: 在我们为《世界发展 》 （ World Development）杂志合作撰写的最新论文中，我们考察了哪些因素推动了成功的减贫。

column1: Using poverty statistics from developing countries during the MDGs era, we assessed whether countries with higher levels of income poverty – that is, more people living on less money – experienced faster reductions in their poverty rates than economies with lower income-poverty levels.
column2: 我们用MDG时期发展中国家的贫困统计数字，评估了是否收入贫困情况更严重的国家 — — 即较多的人依靠较少的钱生活 — — 比收入贫困情况较低的经济体贫困率下降更快。

column1: Using limits of $1.25 and $2 per person per day, we found that poverty tended to decrease faster in countries that started out poorer.
column2: 我们用每人每天1.25美元和2美元为下限和上限，发现起点更穷的国家，贫困率往往下降更快。

column1: But these findings, while positive, tell only part of the story.
column2: 但这些发现虽然积极，仍只是故事的一部分。

column1: In many countries, the end of poverty remains a distant goal.
column2: 在许多国家，消灭贫困仍然是一个遥远的目标。

column1: For example, at the current pace of poverty reduction, we estimate that Mali, where 86% of the population lived on less than $1.25 a day in 1990, will require another 31 years to eradicate extreme poverty altogether.
column2: 比如，按照当前减贫速度，我们估计马里 — — 1990年有86%的人口一天花费不到1.25美元 — — 还需要31年时间完全消除极端贫困。

column1: But even in Ecuador, where only 7% of the population lived on less than $1.25 a day in 1990, eliminating poverty will take at least another decade.
column2: 但即使是厄瓜多尔 — — 1990年只有7%的人口一天生活费不足1.25美元 — — 消除贫困也至少还需要十年。

column1: The differing experiences of countries in Africa and Asia illustrate that while adoption of the MDG agenda did accelerate poverty reduction, the degree of progress has varied widely.
column2: 非洲和亚洲国家的不同经验说明，尽管MDG日程的实施确实加快了减贫速度，但进步的程度各不相同。

column1: In the early 1990s, poverty levels in Nigeria, Lesotho, Madagascar, and Zambia were similar to those in China, Vietnam, and Indonesia.
column2: 20世纪90年代初，尼日利亚、莱索托、马达加斯加和赞比亚贫困率和中国、越南和印度尼西亚相近。

column1: But by the time the MDGs ended in 2015, the Asian countries had reduced levels of poverty dramatically; the African countries had not.
column2: 但到2015年MDG结束时，业洲国家的贫困水平大幅降低；而非洲国家却没有。

column1: This divergence continues.
column2: 差异还在继续。

column1: Today, extreme poverty is mostly contained to Africa; according to the World Bank’s 2018 Poverty and Shared Prosperity report, 27 of the world’s 28 poorest countries are on the continent, and each has a poverty rate above 30%.
column2: 如今，极端贫困主要集中在非洲；据世界银行2018年《贫困与共同繁荣 》 （ Poverty and Shared Prosperity）报告，全世界最穷的28个国家有27个在非洲，其中每个国家的贫困率都高于30 % 。

column1: In fact, at current rates of poverty reduction, more than 300 million people in Sub-Saharan Africa will still be poor in 2030.
column2: 事实上，按照当前减贫速度，撒哈拉以南非洲的3亿多人要一直穷到2030年。

column1: Many factors have contributed to the shifting geography of poverty.
column2: 许多因素导致了贫困地理学的变化。

column1: In Africa, weak economic performance – fueled by conflict, ineffective policies, ethnic fragmentation, and external shocks – has made it more difficult for countries to fund poverty-alleviation programs.
column2: 在非洲，经济表现的低迷 — — 原因包括冲突、政策低效、民族分裂和外部冲击 — — 导致各国难以为减贫计划提供资金。

column1: But the most important factor may be state capacity.
column2: 但最重要的因素也许是国家能力。

column1: After all, weak state institutions cannot effectively deliver public goods and services.
column2: 毕竟，孱弱的国家机构无法有效提供公共品和服务。

column1: Of course, this leads to another question: what factors determine a state’s capacity?
column2: 当然，这导致了另一个问题：哪些因素决定了国家能力？

column1: In general, states work better when ruling elites are bound by limits on their power.
column2: 一般而言，当执政精英的权力受到限制时，国家会运转得更好。

column1: But administrative experience also plays a role.
column2: 但管理经验也起着作用。

column1: China, with a slightly longer period of modern statehood than most of its younger African counterparts, may simply have developed a greater ability to administer its territory.
column2: 中国的现代国家历史只比非洲国家略长，但它就发展出更好的治国能力。

column1: And yet, whatever the reason for the variation, there is no doubt that state capacity is one of the key ingredients for successful poverty reduction.
column2: 但是，不管差异的原因为何，毫无疑问国家能力是减贫成功的关键要素之一。

column1: We found that during the MDGs, high-poverty countries with strong state institutions were able to reduce poverty twice as fast as countries with feeble capacity, and were more likely to achieve the MDGs’ target of halving poverty by 2015.
column2: 我们发现，在MDG期间，贫困率高而国家机构强力的国家的减贫速度可达能力不足国家的两倍，并且更有可能实现到2015年让贫困率降低一半的MDG目标。

column1: Poverty eradication remains a top priority for the 193 governments that have adopted the SDGs.
column2: 消除贫困仍然是接受了SDG的193家政府的重点工作之一。

column1: But as the international community learned from the MDGs, goals do not guarantee progress.
column2: 但国际社会从MDG中汲取的教训是，目标并不会产生进步。

column1: To ensure that the 725 million people who remained in poverty at the end of MDGs period can escape requires investing in programs that aim at building effective states.
column2: 要确保MDG时期结束时仍生活在贫困中的7.25亿人能够摆脱贫困，必须投资于旨在建设高效国家的计划。

column1: Otherwise, an end date for poverty will remain elusive.
column2: 否则，消除贫困将遥遥无期。

column1: A World of Khashoggis
column2: 我们都是卡舒吉

column1: AMMAN – For two months, the brutal murder of the US-based Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi in Saudi Arabia’s consulate in Istanbul, and its geopolitical repercussions, has dominated headlines worldwide.
column2: 发自阿曼 — — 两个月来，旅美沙特记者贾迈勒·卡舒吉（Jamal Khashoggi）在沙特驻伊斯坦布尔领事馆遭残酷杀害的事件及其地缘政治影响占据了全球媒体的头条。

column1: But his case is far from an anomaly.
column2: 但这起事件其实远非特例。

column1: In fact, according to the International Press Institute, violence against journalists and impunity for the perpetrators are “two of the biggest threats to media freedom in our world today.”
column2: 事实上根据国际新闻研究所的说法，针对记者的暴力行为以及肇事者逍遥法外的现象是“当今对世界媒体自由的两项最大威胁 ” 。

column1: Governments often use both carrots and sticks to keep journalists in line.
column2: 政府通常会使用胡萝卜加大棒来使记者就范。

column1: They might reward journalists for toeing the official line, using financial or other kinds of bribes. Those who refuse to be bought, however, may suffer the loss of basic rights (such as passport renewal), or have their reputations destroyed.
column2: 它们会用金钱或其他类型的贿赂来奖赏那些与官方保持统一口径的记者，而那些拒绝被收买的人可能会被剥夺某些基本权利（例如护照续签）或者遭到抹黑。

column1: To this end, some autocratic regimes emulate US President Donald Trump, calling journalists “enemies” who disseminate “fake news.”
column2: 为此，一些专制政权效仿美国总统特朗普，将新闻记者称之为传播“虚假新闻”的“敌人 ” 。

column1: This is a bleak reversal for the United States, a country that has historically set a powerful positive example with its formal and informal mechanisms for protecting freedom of the press and its robust culture of investigative journalism.
column2: 对于美国这个历史上一直以其正式和非正式方式新闻自由保护机制以及蓬勃发展的调查新闻文化树立了强大榜样的国家来说，这堪称是一次不光彩的转向。

column1: Imprisonment is another favorite way for autocratic regimes to silence journalists who dare to speak truth to power.
column2: 而监禁则是专制政权喜欢用来让那些仗义敢言的记者保持沉默的另一种方式。

column1: In Egypt, Al Jazeera’s Mahmoud Hussein has been detained for two years without trial.
column2: 在埃及，半岛电视台的马哈茂德·胡塞因（Mahmoud Hussein）被拘禁了两年还未审判。

column1: In the United Arab Emirates, the Jordanian journalist Tayseer al-Najjar is serving a three-year sentence, which will be prolonged if his family is unable to pay the massive $136,000 fine imposed on him for a post he made on social media.
column2: 在阿联酋，约旦记者塔伊西尔·阿尔-纳贾尔（Tayseer al-Najjar）被判刑三年，而如果他的家人无法为他在社交媒体上发布的一篇文章支付高达13.6万美元的罚款，刑期还会被延长。

column1: In Turkey, more than 150 journalists have been imprisoned since the failed coup in July 2016, making the country the world’s biggest jailer of journalists.
column2: 在土耳其，自2016年7月政变失败以来已有150多名记者被监禁，使该国成为世界上囚禁记者最多的国家。

column1: And then, of course, there are the journalists who are forced to make the ultimate sacrifice in service of the truth.
column2: 当然也有有些记者被迫为真理做出了最大的牺牲。

column1: By one count, 73 journalists have been killed so far this year, and in, 12 countries five or more murders of journalists went unresolved in 2017.
column2: 据统计今年迄今为止已有73名记者被杀，而且在2017年在12个国家内各有5起或更多的谋害记者者未得到惩处。

column1: This includes not only violence-plagued countries like Iraq, Somalia, and Syria, but also democracies (and quasi-democracies) like Brazil, India, Mexico, Nigeria, and Russia.
column2: 这不仅包括伊拉克，索马里和叙利亚等深陷暴力的国家，还包括一些民主国家（和准民主国家 ） ， 如巴西、印度、墨西哥，尼日利亚和俄罗斯。

column1: Such countries – many of which are allies of the US and other Western countries – have often faced no political or diplomatic price for their actions.
column2: 这些国家 — — 其中许多是美国和其他西方国家的盟友 — — 往往并未因此面临政治或外交代价。

column1: In this sense, Khashoggi’s murder sends a powerful message.
column2: 从这个意义上说，卡舒吉谋杀案其实释放出了一个强有力的信息。

column1: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is widely believed to have ordered the killing.
column2: 人们普遍认为是谋杀命令是由沙特王储穆罕默德·本·萨勒曼（Mohammed bin Salman）下达的。

column1: Yet journalists and human-rights activists in developing countries that benefit from or depend on financial support from Saudi Arabia are being politely (or not so politely) requested to keep quiet as MBS tours the region in order to restore his image.
column2: 然而当王储随机前往多个发展中国家访问以恢复其形象时，当地那些受益或依赖于沙特财政支持的记者和人权活动家都被礼貌地（或不那么礼貌地）要求保持沉默。

column1: In many Arab countries, for example, it is a crime to carry out any action or publish anything that could hurt the reputation of “a brotherly or friendly country.”
column2: 例如，在许多阿拉伯国家，任何可能损害“兄弟或友好国家”声誉的行为和文章都是犯罪。

column1: So, while Tunisian human-rights activists protested MBS’s recent visit, many Arab activists had to refrain, despite strongly opposing the Saudi leader’s actions, in order to avoid imprisonment.
column2: 因此当突尼斯人权活动人士对王储近期的访问表示抗议时，许多阿拉伯活动家尽管强烈反对沙特领导人的行径，但却不得不克制自己以免遭到监禁。

column1: Even some Western countries have failed to take a stand.
column2: 甚至一些西方国家也未能挺身而出。

column1: Trump, for example, has declared that he “stands with” Saudi Arabia, a close US ally, largely in order to protect large arms deals with the Kingdom.
column2: 比如特朗普就宣称他与沙特“站在一起 ” ， 但主要是为了保障与这一亲密盟友的大宗武器交易。

column1: Among the few who have been courageous enough to speak out are Palestinian journalists living under Israeli occupation.
column2: 而在少数勇敢发声的人中则有生活在以色列占领下的巴勒斯坦记者。

column1: More than 150 independent Palestinian journalists have signed an Avaaz petition stating that his murder sets “a dangerous precedent that threatens the lives of journalists, their right to free expression, the freedom of journalistic work, and the right of the public to know.”
column2: 150多名独立巴勒斯坦记者联署了一份Avaaz请愿书，声明对他的谋杀案是“一个威胁到记者生命，言论自由权利，新闻工作自由以及公众知情权的危险先例 ” 。

column1: The petition also looks beyond Khashoggi’s case, calling for the enactment of “binding laws that protect journalists, guarantee their right to work in freedom, and punish those who violate this right.”
column2: 该请愿书也把目光放在了卡舒吉的案件之外，要求制定“具有约束力的法律以保护记者，保障他们自由工作的权利，并惩罚侵犯这一权利的人 ” 。

column1: Given how widespread crimes against journalists are – and how vital their work is to our societies – the petition’s demands deserve the support of all citizens where press freedom is restricted or under threat.
column2: 鉴于针对记者的犯罪行为是如此广泛存在 — — 以及他们的工作对我们社会的重要程度 — — 请愿书的要求应得到所有那些新闻自由受限制或受威胁地区公民的支持。

column1: Khrushchev’s Secret Speech and End of Communism
column2: 赫鲁晓夫的秘密讲话与共产主义的终结

column1: In history, some events at first appear insignificant, or their significance is hidden, but they turn out to be earthshaking.
column2: 历史上，有些事件一开始好像无足轻重，或者其重要意义深藏不露，但随着历史的前进，人们才发现这些事件有着惊天动地的意义。

column1: Such a moment occurred 50 years ago, with Nikita Khrushchev’s so-called “Secret Speech” to the Twentieth Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
column2: 50年前就发生了这样一个事件，即所谓的赫鲁晓夫苏共20大“秘密讲话 ” 。

column1: It ranks, I believe, just below the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917 and the start of Hitler’s War in 1939 as the most critical moment of the twentieth century.
column2: 我相信，在20世纪重大事件排行榜上，这一事件仅次于“1917年布尔什维克革命”和1939年爆发的“希特勒战争 ” ， 位列第三。

column1: At that moment, the communist movement appeared to be riding the tide of history, and not only for those in the Soviet Union.
column2: 当时，共产主义运动在苏联和世界各地风起云涌。

column1: In the mid-1950’s, communism was on the offensive in Europe, as well as in the emerging Third World.
column2: 20世纪50年代中期，共产主义在欧洲以及新兴的第三世界范围内咄咄逼人。

column1: Capitalism seemed to be dying.
column2: 资本主义好像就要寿终正寝。

column1: All of communism’s imperfections were deemed temporary, just bumps on the way to the just society that was then being born.
column2: 人们相信，共产主义虽然有不尽如人意之处，但那不过是通向即将诞生的公平社会之路上的颠簸。

column1: A third of humanity saw the Soviet Union as leading the world toward global socialism.
column2: 全世界三分之一的人认为苏联正带领世界走向全球共产主义。

column1: The Twentieth Congress put an end to that.
column2: 苏共20大宣告了这一切的终结。

column1: It was a moment of truth, a cleansing from within of the brutality of Stalinism.
column2: 那是一个获得真相的时刻，从内部清洗斯大林主义的残暴。

column1: Khrushchev’s speech to the Congress inspired doubt and second thoughts throughout the worldwide Communist movement.
column2: 赫鲁晓夫此次大会上的讲话在全世界共产主义运动中引发了怀疑和反思。

column1: Khrushchev’s motives as he took the podium on the morning of February 25, 1956, were, in his mind, moral ones.
column2: 1956年2月25日上午，当赫鲁晓夫站在讲话台上时，他认为他的动机的出于道德考虑。

column1: After his ouster from power, in the seclusion of his dacha, he wrote: “My hands are covered with blood.
column2: 下台之后，在其隐居的乡间别墅里他写道 ： “ 我的双手沾满了鲜血。

column1: I did everything that others did.
column2: 我做了别人所做的一切事情。

column1: But even today if I have to go to that podium to report on Stalin, I would do it again.
column2: 但是即使今天，如果还需要我走上那个讲话台揭露斯大林，我将义无反顾。

column1: One day all that had to be over.”
column2: 总有结束这一切的那一天 。 ”

column1: Khrushchev had, of course, been an intimate part of Stalin’s repressions, but he also didn’t know half of what was going on.
column2: 当然，赫鲁晓夫曾是斯大林专制政权的重要组成部分，但他对所发生的事情也只是知道一半。

column1: The whole Stalinist system of government was built on absolute secrecy, in which only the General Secretary himself knew the whole story.
column2: 斯大林主义的整个政府体系都是建立在绝对保密的基础之上，只有总书记本人知道全部的事情。

column1: It wasn’t terror that was the basis of Stalin’s power, but his complete monopoly on information.
column2: 恐怖并不是斯大林的政权基础，而是他对信息的绝对垄断。

column1: Khrushchev, for example, was stunned when he discovered that in the 1930’s and 1940’s, some 70% of Party members were annihilated.
column2: 例如，当赫鲁晓夫发现在20世纪30年代和40年代大约70%的党员残遭杀害时，他深感震惊。

column1: Initially, Khrushchev didn’t plan to keep his denunciation of Stalin a secret.
column2: 最初，赫鲁晓夫并不打算将其对斯大林的揭露与谴责进行保密。

column1: Five days after the Congress, his speech was sent to all the leaders of the socialist countries and read at local party meetings across the Soviet Union.
column2: 苏共20大结束5天之后，所有的社会主义国家的领导人都收到了他的讲话稿，苏联各地的党代会上也都宣读。

column1: But people didn’t know how to discuss it.
column2: 但是人们不知道如何对之讨论。

column1: And with good reason, for the problem with the de-Stalinization process was that, although the truth was partly revealed, no answer regarding what to do next was offered.
column2: 这是有原因的，因为在非斯大林化进程中的问题是，尽管部分真相得到了披露，但是并没有提供下一步如何行动的答案。

column1: After the Congress, it became clear that the communist gospel was false and murderously corrupt.
column2: 此次大会之后，共产主义福音的虚伪与致命腐败昭然若揭。 但是，并没有提供其他的意识形态。

column1: But no other ideology was offered, and the crisis – the slow rot of the system that became clear during the era of stagnation under Leonid Brezhnev – that began with Khrushchev’s speech lasted another 30 years, until Mikhail Gorbachev took up his mantle of change.
column2: 勃列日涅夫执政的停滞时代这个政权的缓慢腐朽逐渐明显。 赫鲁晓夫讲话始发的危机持续30年之久，直到戈尔巴乔夫扬起改革的大旗。

column1: The doubts inspired at the Congress may have been inchoate, but they nonetheless sowed genuine unrest.
column2: 此次大会激起的怀疑可能尚未成熟，但是却播下了动荡不安的种子。

column1: In the first of the protests that rocked the communist world in 1956, huge crowds in Georgia demanded that Khrushchev be fired and Stalin’s memory reinstated.
column2: 1956年震惊共产主义世界的第一次抗议声浪中，在格鲁吉亚共和国，大批群众要求赫鲁晓夫下台，恢复斯大林名誉。

column1: An uprising in Poland and the far more tumultuous Hungarian Revolution argued for the opposite.
column2: 波兰的起义和比之更为激烈的“匈牙利革命”则持要求相反的东西。

column1: The Poles demanded communism with a human face, and the Hungarians, after Imre Nagy sought to reform communism, ended up wanting no communism at all.
column2: 波兰人要求人性化的共产主义，而匈牙利则在纳吉寻求改良共产主义之后彻底抛弃了共产主义。

column1: All of these protests were brutally crushed, which resulted in many West European Communists leaving the Party in utter disillusion.
column2: 所有这些抗议活动都遭到了残酷的镇压，导致西欧大批共产党员在理想破灭后脱离共产党。

column1: Khrushchev’s speech also ignited the feud between Mao’s China and the USSR, for it allowed Mao to claim the crown of world revolutionary leadership.
column2: 赫鲁晓夫的讲话还导致毛的中国与苏联不和，因为它给毛戴上了世界革命领袖的桂冠。

column1: Worried by the protests, Khrushchev tried to cool off the anti-Stalin campaign.
column2: 赫鲁晓夫对这些抗议活动忧心忡忡，试图平息这场反斯大林运动。

column1: The release of the Gulag prisoners that followed his speech continued, but it was done in silence.
column2: 发表讲话后开始释放古拉格政治犯继续进行，但却悄无声息。

column1: Party membership was restored to purge survivors, and they received new jobs, but they were forbidden from discussing the horrors that they had endured.
column2: 清洗运动中的幸存者被恢复了党籍，安排了新的工作，但却禁止议论其遭遇。

column1: That silence lasted until 1961, when Khrushchev permitted new revelations of Stalin-era crimes.
column2: 这种压制持续到1961年，赫鲁晓夫允许再次揭露斯大林时代的罪恶。

column1: These were publicly reported and discussed on TV and radio.
column2: 电视和电台公开报道和讨论这些罪恶。

column1: Stalin’s body was removed from Red Square, Stalin monuments were destroyed, and cities restored their original Soviet names.
column2: 斯大林的遗体被迁离红场，斯大林纪念碑被破坏，并且各个城市都恢复了原来苏联的名字。

column1: Stalingrad became Volgograd.
column2: 斯大林格勒更名为伏尔加格勒。

column1: The idea of the Gulag entered our literature with Alexander Solzhenitsyn’s One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich.
column2: 苏联古拉格中的思想随着亚历山大·索忍尼辛《伊凡的一天》进入了我们的文学作��之中。

column1: This second anti-Stalinist campaign lasted two years, which was not nearly enough to change the country’s mentality.
column2: 第二场反斯大林运动持续了2年，还不足以改变这个国家的思想状况。

column1: The Twentieth Congress shattered the world Communist movement, and it turned out to be impossible to cement the cracks.
column2: 苏共20大粉碎了世界共产主义运动，并且这些碎片再也无法粘合。

column1: The Soviet Union and other socialist countries faced a crisis of faith, as the main threat to communism was not imperialism, or ideological dissidents, but the movement’s own intellectual poverty and disillusion.
column2: 苏联和其它社会主义国家都面临着一场信仰危机，因为共产主义的主要威胁不是帝国主义或意识形态上的持不同政见者，而是这场运动本身智识贫乏以及理想破灭。

column1: So, although it is common today in Russia to blame Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin for the collapse of the USSR, it is both useless and unfair to do so.
column2: 因此，虽然俄罗斯普遍指责戈尔巴乔夫和叶利钦导致苏联解体，但这样做既没用，也不公平。

column1: The system was dead already, and it is to Yeltsin’s great credit that he was able to bring Russia out of the ruins in one piece.
column2: 这个政权体制已经死了，能够带领俄罗斯完整地走出废墟也应归功于叶利钦。

column1: Although Russia’s future is uncertain, its history is becoming clearer, in part because we now know that the Twentieth Party Congress started the process that brought about the end of Soviet despotism.
column2: 虽然俄罗斯前途未谱，但它的历史变得更加清晰，部分原因是因为我们现在知道苏共20大开启了苏联专制的终结。

column1: Kicking the Oil Habit
column2: 打击耗油习惯

column1: Chancellor Angela Merkel has made addressing climate change a high priority on Germany’s agenda for its EU and G-8 presidencies that begin in January.
column2: 德国总理默克尔已经将处理气候变化作为将于一月开始的德国担任欧盟和八国集团轮值主席国的高度优先问题。

column1: Here is a concrete proposal, one general enough for world leaders to consider and accept, and clear enough for other governments and businesses to grasp: simply set a date, at the next G-8 summit, by which oil-powered cars would no longer be licensed in major industrialized countries.
column2: 不妨提出一个具体的提议，那就是在下一届八国集团首脑会议上制定一个日期，从这一日期以后，主要工业化国家都将不再给由汽油驱动的汽车颁发执照。 这一提议十分通用，足以让世界各国领导人考虑以及接受，而且十分明晰，足以让其他国家政府和工商界人士来加以领会。

column1: Such a decision would have a strongly positive economic and geopolitical impact.
column2: 这一决定将会产生极为积极的经济和地缘政治影响。

column1: The real cause of today’s worries over energy is not the decline in world oil reserves, but rather that domestic oil production by the top consumers – Europe, the United States, and China – will decline at the very moment that growing Asian demand strains the market.
column2: 如今对于能源的担忧的实际原因并非是世界石油储备的下降，而是最大石油消费国，例如欧洲、美国和中国的国内石油生产在不断增长的亚洲国家需求拖累市场之际下降。

column1: Available reserves will increasingly be concentrated in the Middle East simply because supplies in all other regions will be depleted sooner.
column2: 现有的储备将日益集中在中东，简单的原因就是所有其他地区的储备将会提前耗尽。

column1: Moreover, the main oil exporters are unwilling to subordinate their investment policies to market requirements.
column2: 而且，主要石油出口国不愿意将它们的投资政策屈从于市场要求。

column1: Saudi Arabia seeks to run its oil production independently, while Iran scares off potential investors with bureaucratic hurdles and corruption.
column2: 沙特阿拉伯寻求独立自主地进行石油生产，伊朗以官僚主义障碍和腐败吓跑潜在的投资者。

column1: Iraq suffers from a lack of security, and foreign investors in Russia are thwarted at every turn.
column2: 伊拉克苦于缺乏安全，而外国投资者在俄罗斯四处碰壁。

column1: Those four states contain half of the world’s proven oil reserves and two-thirds of what could potentially be exported.
column2: 这四个国家拥有世界探明储备的一半以及可能出口的石油的三分之二。

column1: All this, not production costs, lies at the heart of high oil prices and the scramble for oil contracts in Central Asia and Africa.
column2: 所有这些、而非生产成本是高油价以及追逐中亚和非洲石油合同的本因。

column1: To believe that high oil prices are good because they serve the environment ignores some basic facts of international politics.
column2: 因为对于环境有益而相信高油价是好事就忽略了某些国际关系的基本事实。

column1: First, in many of the poorest African and Asian countries, oil imports account for a significantly higher share of national expenditure than in industrialized countries, which means that economic growth and social development are being imperiled, while new debt crises loom.
column2: 首先，许多最穷的亚非国家与工业化国家相比，石油进口在国民支出上占据明显更高的比重。 这就意味着，它们的经济增长以及社会发展受到阻碍，而新的债务危机则呼之欲来。

column1: Rents from oil production impede reforms in the major exporting countries.
column2: 石油生产的特许权收入阻碍了主要石油出口国的改革。

column1: Thanks to their lubricated financial strength, regimes like those in Venezuela and Iran increasingly feel unconstrained by international rules.
column2: 由于其丰厚的金融实力，像委内瑞拉和伊朗等政权越发感到可以不受国际规则的制约，为所欲为。

column1: Latecomers among consuming nations, such as China, mimic the former habits of the industrialized West, with their long record of overlooking human rights abuses in order to secure lucrative deals with authoritarian, oil-rich regimes.
column2: 像中国那样的后来的石油消费国模仿西方工业化国家的旧有习惯，长久以来漠视践踏人权的事例从而与独裁的石油大国政权签定丰厚的合同。

column1: Only the world’s political and economic heavyweights, the main industrialized countries that remain by far the biggest consumers of hydrocarbons, can initiate change on a global scale.
column2: 只有当今世界的政治和经济重量级国家、也就是那些碳氢化合物最大的消费国家才能够在全球范围内发动改变。

column1: Change must begin in the transport sector, which accounts for more than half of current oil consumption – a share that is likely to rise in the future.
column2: 改变必须从交通行业开始，这一行业占据目前石油消费的一半以上，而且这一比重今后可能会提高。

column1: The G-8 countries should therefore agree to no longer license any new, oil-powered cars from 2025 onwards.
column2: 因此，工业八强国家应当同意从2025年以后不再给任何新的、以石油为动力的汽车颁发执照。

column1: This decision would not be directed against individual mobility, but against the dissipation of a scarce resource that is more urgently needed to produce synthetic materials.
column2: 这一决定将不会针对个人的行动自由，而是针对制造合成材料上更为迫切需要的稀缺资源的消失。

column1: Political leaders should not privilege any particular technology.
column2: 政治领导人不应当给予任何特别的技术以关照。

column1: Instead, they should provide the automobile industry with incentives to develop alternative technologies that rely on bio-mass fuel, ethylene, hydrogen, and even natural gas during a transition period.
column2: 相反，他们应该给汽车产业提供激励，发展在过渡时期内依赖于生物燃料、乙烯、氢甚至是天然气的替换性技术。

column1: Countries that lead the way politically will, as a collateral benefit, provide domestic industries with a leading position in energy technology, ensuring future markets.
column2: 在政治上发挥领导作用的国家将为国内产业在能源技术上提供领先地位，从而确保未来的市场，而这也是一项附带的利益。

column1: The expected significant reduction of CO2-emissions could eventually bring about the breakthrough that is needed in international climate policies.
column2: 预期的大幅度降低二氧化碳排放最终可以带来在国际气候政策中所需要的突破。

column1: But economic development comes into play as well: curing our “addiction” to oil would leave more of it to poorer, less developed, and newly industrializing countries, as well as pushing down prices and easing geopolitical energy competition.
column2: 但是，经济发展也发挥作用，那就是，治疗我们对石油的“上瘾”将会把更多的石油留给较为贫困、发展落后以及新兴的工业化国家，同时压低价格，消除地缘政治的能源竞争。

column1: Geopolitically, the benefits would similarly obvious, as the ability of major oil exporters to blackmail industrialized countries would be significantly reduced.
column2: 从地缘政治角度而言，其利益也是同样明显的，因为主要石油出口国要挟工业化国家的能力将会被显著降低。

column1: This could increase the bargaining power of the international community in the Middle East, and might strengthen those social forces in countries like Saudi Arabia, Iran, and Russia that seriously wish to promote political and economic reform from within.
column2: 这将会提高国际社会在中东的讨价还价的实力，而且可能加强像沙特、伊朗以及俄罗斯等国的那些确实愿意从内部促进政治和经济改革的社会力量。

column1: As a technologically advanced and major automobile-producing country, Germany is well placed to bring about such an initiative.
column2: 德国技术先进，而且是主要汽车制造国，具有提出这样一种倡议的地位。

column1: Merkel, who holds a doctorate in physics and started her political career as an environment minister – presiding in 1995 over the first conference of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change – may have more credibility in addressing the issue than any of her EU and G-8 colleagues.
column2: 默克尔拥有物理学博士学位，其政治生涯从环境部长开始，1995年主持了首届联合国关于气候变化的框架会议，因此，在处理这一问题上要比她的欧盟和工业八强的同事们更为具有信誉度。

column1: Now is the time for a bold act of leadership.
column2: 现在就是做出果敢的领导性行动的时候了。

column1: Kick-Starting Employment
column2: 启动就业

column1: BERKELEY – Unemployment is currently rising like a rocket, because businesses that normally would be expanding and hiring are not, and those businesses that would normally be contracting and shedding workers are doing so very rapidly.
column2: 美国伯克利报道－失业情况目前正如火箭一样飞速上升，因为要进行正常业务发展而需要招聘人才的企业没有得到发展，而那些通常要减员增效的企业则迅速地执行着其任务。

column1: Businesses that ought to be expanding and hiring cannot, because the depressed general level of financial asset prices prevents them from borrowing money or selling bonds on profitable terms.
column2: 那些因扩展业务而需招聘人才的企业无法做到这样，是因为金融资产的价格下降的普遍水平让它们无法按照有利可图的条款从外界获得贷款或售出自己的债券。

column1: In response, central banks should purchase government bonds for cash in as large a quantity as needed to push their prices up as high as possible.
column2: 作为对这种情况的回应，中央银行应该以必须的大数量现金买入债券，以此来将债券的价格尽可能地抬高。

column1: Expensive government bonds will shift demand to mortgage or corporate bonds, pushing up their prices.
column2: 昂贵的政府债券则会将这种需求转移到抵押贷款或公司债券，以此抬高自己的价格。

column1: Even after central banks have pushed government bond prices as high as they can go, they should keep buying government bonds for cash, in the hope that people whose pockets are full of cash will spend more of it, and that this will directly pull people out of joblessness and into employment.
column2: 即使在中央银行把政府债券的价格抬到它们能力所能的高价格，央行仍应该不断地买入政府债券以积累资金，以此希望那些口袋满是现金的人能多花些钱，并且也希望这样能直接让人们摆脱失业的困境而走向就业。

column1: In addition, governments need to run extra-large deficits.
column2: 此外，政府需要启动超额的大赤字。

column1: Spending – whether by the United States government during World War II, following the Reagan tax cuts of 1981, by Silicon Valley during the late 1990’s, or by home buyers in America’s south and on its coasts in the 2000’s – boosts employment and reduces unemployment.
column2: 无论是美国政府在二战期间的开支，还是在里根减税政策之后的20世纪90年代的硅谷的开支，或是21世纪初美国南部购房者在南部港口的开支，都能促进就业，减少失业问题。

column1: And government spending is as good as anybody else’s.
column2: 而政府开支能与其它的开支有着同等的力量。

column1: Finally, governments should undertake additional measures to boost financial asset prices, and so make it easier for those firms that ought to be expanding and hiring to obtain finance on terms that allow them to expand and hire.
column2: 最后，政府应该承诺采取额外措施来促进金融资产价格的上升，这样才能让那么本应当扩展业务并招募新人才的企业能以优惠的条件获取金融支持来扩展业务并招募人才。

column1: It is this point that brings us to US Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner’s plan to take about $465 billion of government money, combine it with $35 billion of private-sector money, and use it to buy up risky financial assets.
column2: 也就是这最后一点让我们聚焦于美国财政部长蒂莫西·盖特纳的计划 — — 拿出政府4650亿美元的资金，与私有企业的350亿美元相结合，并用之于买入风险性的金融资产。

column1: The US Treasury is asking the private sector to put $35 billion into this $500 billion fund so that the fund managers all have some “skin in the game,” and thus do not take excessive risks with the taxpayers’ money.
column2: 美国财政部要求私有企业拿出350亿资金加入总共5000亿的资金中来，因此基金公司的经理就能拥有些许“脸面 ” ， 这样就不会被指责拿着纳税人的钱去冒过多的风险了。

column1: Private-sector investors ought to be more than willing to kick in that $35 billion, for they stand to make a fortune when financial asset prices close some of the gap between their current and normal values.
column2: 私有企业的投资人应该表现得更加情愿地拿出钱凑足350亿美元，因为当金融资产价格在它们目前的价值与正常价值没有任何差异时，它们就能赚上一笔。

column1: If the fund does well over the next five years – returns profits of 9% per year –private investors get a market rate of return on their very risky equity investment and the equivalent of an “annual management fee” equal to 2% of assets under management.
column2: 如果资金在今后的5年里表现不错的话 — — 回报率在每年9 % — —那么私有投资人以他们自己风险性较大的产权投资获得市场回报率，以及等同于2%资产管理费的“年管理费 ” 。

column1: If the portfolio does less well – profits of 4% per year – the managers still get a healthy but sub-market return of 10% per year on their equity.
column2: 如果投资表现不够理想 — — 年利润率在4 % — —基金经理们仍能以他们的产权投资为基础得到相当丰厚的10%次市场利润率。

column1: And if the portfolio does badly – loses 1% per year – they lose roughly 70% of their investment.
column2: 如果投资表现得很糟糕 — — 每年亏损1 % — —那他们则会失去投资总额的70 % 。

column1: Those are attractive odds.
column2: 这些都是引人入胜的几率。

column1: Time alone will tell whether the financiers who invest in and run this program make a fortune.
column2: 只有时间能告诉我们，投入资金并经营这个项目的金融投资人是否能赚到钱。

column1: But if they do, they will make the US government an even bigger fortune.
column2: 如果能赚的话，那他们给美国政府带来的财富则会更丰盛。

column1: And 2% of assets under management is an annual fee that many sophisticated investors have been willing to pay private hedge funds – topped off with an extra fee of 20% of annual profits, which the Treasury is not paying.
column2: 而像2%的资产管理费这样的年费，许多久经世故的投资人都会愿意拿来支付私人对冲基金 — — 最终要花费掉年利润中的20%做为额外费用，美国财政部不会支付这笔费用。

column1: The fact that the Geithner Plan is likely to be profitable for the US government is, however, a sideshow.
column2: 然而，盖特纳计划可能会让美国政府获取利润的事实却是一个滑稽闹剧。

column1: The aim is to reduce unemployment.
column2: 该计划的目的是减少失业。

column1: The appearance of an extra $500 billion in demand for risky assets will reduce the quantity of risky assets that other private investors will have to hold.
column2: 为买入危险性资产而需要的额外5000亿美元的出现将减少危险资产的数量，这些是私有投资人所必须持有的。

column1: And the sudden appearance of between five and ten different government-sponsored funds that make public bids for assets will convey information to the markets about what models other people are using to try to value assets in this environment.
column2: ��5或10种不同的政府赞助且需要公众竞相购买的基金的突然出现将向市场传达一个讯息，即在这种环境之下，其他人在为资产估值时会使用什么模式。

column1: This sharing of information will reduce risk – somewhat.
column2: 信息的共享多少能减少风险。

column1: When assets are seen as less risky, their prices rise.
column2: 当资产的风险性看似不大时，它们的价格就能上升。

column1: And when there are fewer assets to be held, their prices rise, too.
column2: 而当资产的持有率少之又少时，资产的价格也能上升。

column1: With higher financial asset prices, those firms that ought to be expanding and hiring will be able to get money on more attractive terms.
column2: 金融资产的价格越高，那些本该扩展业务并招募人才的企业将能够以更有优势的条件获得利润。

column1: The problem is that the Geithner Plan appears to me to be too small – between one-eight and one-half of what it needs to be.
column2: 问题在于，盖特纳计划对我来说规模太小 — — 只达到了它所应有程度的八分之一与五分之一之间。

column1: Even though the US government is doing other things as well –fiscal stimulus, quantitative easing, and other uses of bailout funds – it is not doing everything it should.
column2: 尽管美国政府也在进行其它事务 — — 财政刺激、定量放松，并使用了其它救援资金 — — 但盖特纳计划没有做好它应该完成的一切。

column1: My guess is that the reason that the US government is not doing all it should can be stated in three words: Senator George Voinovich, who is the 60th vote in the Senate – the vote needed to close off debate and enact a bill.
column2: 我猜想，美国政府没有做到它应该做的一切的原因能以三个字来描述：参议员约翰·沃诺维奇，他是参议院的第60投票，这个投票是结束辩论并通过一项法案的必须的投票。

column1: To do anything that requires legislative action, the Obama administration needs Voinovich and the 59 other senators who are more inclined to support it.
column2: 要做任何需要立法行为的事情，奥巴马政府都沃诺维奇与其他更加支持他的59为议员。

column1: The administration’s tacticians appear to think that they are not on board – especially after the recent AIG bonus scandal – whereas the Geithner Plan relies on authority that the administration already has.
column2: 奥巴马政府的战略家们似乎认为他们无权干涉此事，特别四在最近美国国际集团的奖金丑闻事件之后，而盖特纳计划却依赖于政府现有的权威人士。

column1: Doing more would require a legislative coalition that is not there yet.
column2: 要达到更大的目标需要一个立法联合，但这种联合现在还没有形成。

column1: Kidney for Sale
column2: 待售的肾

column1: NEW HAVEN – World Kidney Day, to be held on March 12, is part of a global health campaign meant to alert us to the impact of kidney disease.
column2: 纽黑文—3月12日是世界肾脏日，也是旨在让人们警惕肾脏疾病的全球健康活动的组成部分之一。

column1: Sadly, there is little to celebrate.
column2: 悲哀的是，没有什么可庆祝的。

column1: According to the International Society of Nephrology, kidney disease affects more than 500 million people worldwide, or 10% of the adult population.
column2: 根据国际肾病学会的消息，世界范围内有超过5亿人受到肾脏疾病的影响，或者说是成年人的10 % 。

column1: With more people developing high blood pressure and diabetes (key risks for kidney disease), the picture will only worsen.
column2: 随着越来越多的人身患高血压和糖尿病（这是肾脏疾病带来的的主要危险 ） ， 情况只会变得更糟。

column1: There are 1.8 million new cases of the most serious form of kidney disease – renal failure – each year.
column2: 最严重的肾脏疾病—肾衰竭—每年会新增180万例。

column1: Unless patients with renal failure receive a kidney transplant or undergo dialysis – an expensive life-long procedure that cleanses the blood of toxins – death is guaranteed within a few weeks.
column2: 除非肾衰竭患者接受肾移植或是进行透析（这种程序可以清楚血液内的毒素，但是价格昂贵，还要持续终生 ） ， 几周之内就会死亡。

column1: Last year, an Australian nephrologist, Gavin Carney, held a press conference in Canberra to urge that people be allowed to sell their kidneys.
column2: 去年，澳大利亚肾病学家嘉文·卡尼在堪培拉举行了一次新闻发布会，主张应该允许人们出售他们的肾脏。

column1: “The current system isn't working,” the Sydney Morning Herald quoted him as saying. “We’ve tried everything to drum up support” for organ donation, but “people just don’t seem willing to give their organs away for free.”
column2: “现行制度不起作用 ” ， 《悉尼先驱晨报》援引他的话说 ： “ 我们已经竭尽所能来争取支持”器官捐赠，但是“人们似乎就是不愿意免费献出他们的器官 ” 。

column1: Carney wants to keep patients from purchasing kidneys on the black market and in overseas organ bazaars.
column2: 卡尼想要阻止病人从黑市或是海外器官市场购买肾脏。

column1: As an American recipient of a kidney who was once desperate enough to consider doing that myself (fortunately, a friend ended up donating to me), I agree wholeheartedly that we should offer well-informed individuals a reward if they are willing to save a stranger’s life.
column2: 作为一位美国的肾脏接受者，我也曾经绝望到想要这样做，幸运的是一位朋友离世的时候把肾脏捐给了我。 我全心全意地赞同：如果有人在了解情况后愿意拯救陌生人的生命，我们应该报答他。

column1: If not, we will continue to face a dual tragedy: on one side, the thousands of patients who die each year for want of a kidney; on the other side, a human-rights disaster in which corrupt brokers deceive indigent donors about the nature of surgery, cheat them out of payment, and ignore their post-surgical needs.
column2: 如果不这样做，我们将继续面对双重悲剧：一方面，每年有数千位病人因为没有肾源而死亡；另一方面，腐败的掮客就手术的性质对贫穷的捐献者进行欺骗，骗走他们的酬劳，忽视他们手术后的需要，引发了人权灾难。

column1: The World Health Organization estimates that 5% to 10% of all transplants performed annually – perhaps 63,000 in all – take place in the clinical netherworlds of China, Pakistan, Egypt, Colombia, and Eastern Europe.
column2: 国际卫生组织估计每年大约总计为63000的移植手术中，有5%到10%发生在中国、巴基斯坦、埃及、哥伦比亚和东欧最下层的诊所里。

column1: Unfortunately, much of the world transplant establishment – including the WHO, the international Transplantation Society, and the World Medical Association – advocates only a partial remedy.
column2: 不幸的是，大部分世界移植机构（包括世界卫生组织，国际移植协会，世界医学协会）都赞成只进行部分补偿。

column1: They�focus on ending organ trafficking but ignore the time-tested truth that trying to stamp out illicit markets either drives them further underground or causes corruption to�reappear elsewhere.
column2: 他们关注的焦点是终止器官走私，却忽视了一条经过时间验证的真理：试图消灭地下违法市场不是让它们转入更地下，就是使得腐败在其他地方再次出现。

column1: For example, after China, India, and Pakistan began cracking down on illicit organ markets, many patients turned to the Philippines.
column2: 例如，在中国、印度和巴基斯坦开始打击地下器官市场之后，许多病人转向菲律宾。

column1: Last spring, after the Philippines banned the sale of kidneys to foreigners, a headline in the Jerusalem Post read, “Kidney Transplant Candidates in Limbo after Philippines Closes Gates.”
column2: 当菲律宾去年春季禁止向外国人出售肾脏之后 ， 《 耶路撒冷邮报》出现了这样的大字标题 ： “ 菲律宾关闭大门之后, Limbo的肾移植候选者 ” 。

column1: (Israel has one of the lowest donation rates in the world, so the government pays for transplant surgery performed outside the country.)
column2: （以色列是全球捐献率最低的国家之一，因此政府会给境外的移植手术付费。

column1: Similarly, patients from Qatar who traveled to Manila are “looking for alternative solutions,” according to The Peninsula .
column2: ）同样，据《半岛日报》报道，前往马尼拉的卡塔尔患者正在“寻找替代的解决办法 ” 。

column1: True, more countries must develop efficient systems for posthumous donation, a very important source of organs.
column2: 的确，更多的国家必须发展高效的死后捐赠体制，这是一个重要的器官源。

column1: But even in Spain, which is famously successful at retrieving organs from the newly deceased, people die while waiting for a kidney.
column2: 但是，即便在以成功使新近死者身上的器官得以再生利用而闻名于世的西班牙，人们依然会在等待肾源的过程中死去。

column1: The truth is that trafficking will stop only when the need for organs disappears.
column2: 事实是：只有不需要器官的时候，走私才能停止。

column1: Opponents allege that a legal system of exchange will inevitably replicate the sins of the black market.
column2: 反对者声称，合法的交换体制将会不可避免地复制黑市里的罪恶。

column1: This is utterly backward.
column2: 这完全是一种落后的观念。

column1: The remedy to this corrupt and unregulated system of exchange is a regulated and transparent regime devoted to donor protection.
column2: 为了纠正这种腐败堕落、不受控制的交易体制，可以施行一种受到管理，公开透明，致力于保护捐献者的新体制。

column1: My colleagues and I suggest a system in which compensation is provided by a third party (government, a charity, or insurance) with public oversight.
column2: 我的同事和我建议建立这样一种体制，其中补偿由第三方（政府，慈善机构，保险公司）来提供，受到公众监督。

column1: Because bidding and private buying would not be permitted, available organs would be distributed to the next in line – not just to the wealthy.
column2: 因为不允许竞价和私下购买，获得的器官将会分给下一个等候者，而不是仅仅分给富人。

column1: Donors would be carefully screened for physical and psychological problems, as is currently done for all volunteer living kidney donors.
column2: 捐献者将会接受身体和心理方面的仔细筛选，就象现在所有活体肾脏的志愿捐献者所作的一样。

column1: Moreover, they would be guaranteed follow-up�care for any complications.
column2: 而且，还会保证他们的任何并发症都会受到后续护理。

column1: Many people are uneasy about offering lump-sum cash payments.
column2: 许多人都为提供一次性的现金偿付感到担心。

column1: A solution is to provide in-kind rewards – such as a down payment on a house, a contribution to a retirement fund, or lifetime health insurance – so that the program would not be attractive to people who might otherwise rush to donate on the promise of a large sum of instant cash.
column2: 解决方法之���是提供实物回报，例如一栋房子的首付，捐给退休基金的一笔款子，或是终生的健康保险，以便这个项目不会吸引这样一批人：为了马上收到一大笔现金的承诺，他们就会冲过去捐肾。

column1: The only way to stop illicit markets is to create legal ones.
column2: 阻止地下违法市场的唯一途径就是建立合法市场。

column1: Indeed, there is no better justification for testing legal modes of exchange than the very depredations of the underground market.
column2: 的确，试行合法交易模式的最佳辩护理由就是地下市场正在进行大肆掠夺。

column1: Momentum is growing.
column2: 这种势头正在加强。

column1: In the British Medical Journal , a leading British transplant surgeon called for a controlled donor compensation program for unrelated live donors.
column2: 英国一位著名的移植外科大夫在《英国医学杂志》上号召为非亲活体捐赠者通过一个加以控制的捐献者补偿计划。

column1: Within the last year, the Israeli, Saudi, and Indian governments have decided to offer incentives ranging from lifelong health insurance for the donor to a cash benefit.
column2: 过去一年中，以色列、沙特和印度政府已经决定提供奖励，范围涉及捐赠者的终生健康保险到现金收益。

column1: In the United States, the American Medical Association has endorsed a draft bill that would make it easier for states to offer various non-cash incentives for donation.
column2: 在美国，美国医学会已经批准了一项议案草案，使得各州能够更方便地为捐献行为提供各种非现金的奖励。

column1: Until countries create legal means of rewarding donors, the fates of Third World donors and the patients who need their organs to survive will remain morbidly entwined.
column2: 除非各国创立出酬劳捐赠者的合法方式，第三世界捐赠者的命运和需要器官移植来存活下去的病人的命运将会继续可怕地缠绕在一起。

column1: What better way to mark World Kidney Day than for global health leaders to take a bold step and urge countries to experiment with donor rewards?
column2: 对于关注世界肾脏日来说，还有比全球的健康领袖们迈出勇敢的一步，敦促各国试行为捐赠者提供回报更好的方法吗？

column1: Killer Fish Farms
column2: 养鱼场杀手

column1: A recent report by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization found that almost half of all the fish eaten worldwide are raised on fish farms rather than caught in the wild.
column2: 根据最近由联合国粮农组织发表的一份报告显示我们所吃的鱼几乎有一半来自养鱼场而不是野生的。

column1: It is likely that consumption of no other fish has soared more than that of farmed salmon, with production surging by almost 300% in 20 years.
column2: 在此方面，养殖鲑鱼的消费量增长应该是最快的，它的产量在过去20年间急剧上升了大约300 % 。

column1: Salmon are carnivorous, however, and to feed the voracious appetite of these legions of farm-raised fish, the aquaculture industry increasingly has turned its attention to a small crustacean commonly known as Antarctic krill.
column2: 然而，鲑鱼是食肉动物，为了满足这些大批的人工养殖的鱼类的贪婪的食欲，水产业开始越来越多地把他们的注意力放在了一种通常叫做南极磷虾的很小的甲壳纲动物身上。

column1: But that’s bad news for leopard seals and Adelie penguins, humpback and blue whales, and many other species, because most organisms in the Antarctic marine ecosystem eat either krill or something that eats krill.
column2: 但是那对于海豹、阿黛利企鹅、座头鲸、蓝鲸以及其他许多物种来说却是一个坏消息，因为绝大部分南极海洋生态系统的生物体依靠吃磷虾或者其他吃磷虾的东西为生。

column1: Found in the cold waters of the Southern Ocean, krill constitute a key ingredient in fish oil and feed.
column2: 这种在南大洋冰冷的海水里发现的磷虾是鱼的油脂和饲料的一种重要成分。

column1: Unfortunately, recent research indicates that expanded krill fishing might put the Antarctic ecosystem at risk.
column2: 不幸的是，最近的研究显示被扩大的磷虾捕捉会威胁到南极的生态系统。

column1: Representatives from the world’s major fishing nations, meeting this fall in Australia, have an opportunity to limit krill catches, thereby helping creatures that need krill to survive.
column2: 来自世界上主要捕鱼国的代表今年秋天聚集在澳大利亚商议限制磷虾的捕捉量以此来帮助那些以磷虾为生的生物。

column1: Although each krill may only grow to weigh about two grams, together they constitute one of the most abundant animal species on Earth.
column2: 尽管一只磷虾只能长到2克重，但是合在一起它们却组成了地球上动物种群之一。

column1: Indeed, krill form the largest known aggregation of marine life, with a biomass perhaps greater than any other multi-cellular animal organism on the planet.
column2: 事实上，磷虾是海洋生命中数量最为庞大的物种，其数量也许比地球上任何其他多分子的动物都要多。

column1: This “pink gold” forms the heart of the Antarctic marine food web, and land-based krill predators, such as penguins and seals, are most vulnerable to krill scarcity.
column2: 这种“红金色”的动物是南极海洋食物链的核心，而一些在陆地活动的食磷虾的动物，如企鹅和海豹，面对磷虾数量的减少会显得尤其脆弱。

column1: Scientists have found that demand for krill has begun to exceed supply in some areas of the Southwest Atlantic.
column2: 科学家们已经发现南极洲的西南部分的一些地区磷虾的数量已经无法满足需求了。

column1: As a result, penguins and albatrosses already experience difficulty rearing their offspring in areas such as South Georgia.
column2: 其结果是，在像南乔治亚岛这样的一些地区企鹅和信天翁在哺育它们的后代方面已经开始面临很大的困难。

column1: And yet krill fishing is projected to grow.
column2: 然而人们还在计划扩大磷虾的捕捉量。

column1: The Southern Ocean contains the largest population of krill in the world.
column2: 南大洋有着世界上最多的磷虾。

column1: As krill tend to aggregate in concentrated swarms, they are easy to catch and have become particularly attractive to large-scale commercial interests.
column2: 因为磷虾喜欢成群结队地活动，所以它们很容易被捕捉因而特别容易吸引大规模商业利益的兴趣。

column1: Moreover, krill fishing has recently been fueled by new technological advances such as vacuum pumps, which allow a single fishing vessel to catch and process huge amounts – up to 120,000 metric tons per season.
column2: 此外，最近一些新的科技进展更加促进了磷虾的捕捉。 比如说真空泵，它使得一只捕鱼船就能捕捉和加工极大数量的磷虾，每个季节超过12万公吨。

column1: Furthermore, demand for krill products – from fish oil and feed to skin creams and other cosmetics – has increased over the past 20 years.
column2: 另外，对于磷虾产品的需求，从鱼油、鱼饲料到面霜和其他化妆品在过去20年间也变得越来越大。

column1: As wild fish populations continue to decrease, in tandem with an ever-growing global appetite for seafood, the pressure on the aquaculture industry for fish feed will skyrocket.
column2: 因为野生鱼类的数量在不断地减少，加上全球对于海产品越来越大的需求，水产业迫切需要大量的鱼饲料。

column1: The increased demand for krill, together with the new catching and processing capabilities, has combined in a way that the Antarctic ecosystem might not be able to withstand.
column2: 对于磷虾越来越大的需求量，以及新的捕捉和加工能力，使得南极的生态系统越来越难以承受。

column1: But there is hope.
column2: 但是希望还是有的。

column1: The Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR) was established in 1982, as part of the Antarctic Treaty System, in response to concerns that continued unregulated fishing might undermine the basis of the Antarctic food chain.
column2: 作为南极协约系统的一部分，成立于1982的南极海洋生命资源保护公约（CCAMLR）就是对持续无限制的捕捉会破坏南极食物链的基础的担忧的回应。

column1: The CCAMLR is governed by a commission of 24 member states – including Argentina, Australia, Chile, Japan, Norway, Russia, South Africa, South Korea, Ukraine, the United States and the European Union – that meets annually in Hobart, Australia, to discuss new fishing regulations concerning marine species in the Southern Ocean.
column2: 南极海洋生命资源保护公约由一个由24个成员国所组成的委员管理，包括阿根廷、澳大利亚、智利、日本、挪威、俄罗斯、南非、韩国、乌克兰、美国和欧盟。 它们每年在澳大利亚的霍巴特聚会讨论关于在南大洋捕捉海洋物种的新的规定。

column1: The CCAMLR has pioneered ecosystem and precautionary approaches to fisheries management, which are now central to maintaining Antarctic krill.
column2: 南极海洋生命资源保护公约倡导在渔业管理上重视生态系统和采取谨慎的捕捉方法，现在他们把这用在了对于南极磷虾的保护上。

column1: Although the needs of krill-dependent species were previously considered for large areas of the Southern Ocean, the CCAMLR must still scientifically subdivide the overall catch limit into smaller units.
column2: 尽管人们以前认为以磷虾为生的物种生活在南大洋的大片地区，南极海洋生命资源保护公约依然必须科学地把总体上的捕捉限制再加以细分。

column1: This would help avoid local competition between krill vessels and the creatures that need krill to live, since krill fishing closely overlaps with the critical foraging areas for penguins and seals.
column2: 这将有助于避免捕捉磷销的船只与依靠磷销为升的生物之间的竞争，因为磷虾的捕捉区域与企鹅和海豹觅食的重要区域严重重叠。

column1: The CCAMLR’s members must honor the organization’s mandate for conservation and ensure that there is enough “pink gold” to feed the penguins and other wildlife that depend on it.
column2: 南极海洋生命资源保护公约的成员国必须执行该组织关于保护物种的指令并且确保有足够的这种“红金色”动物供给企鹅和其他以此为生的野生生命。

column1: The CCAMLR should also apply to krill fishing the same monitoring, control, and surveillance measures that it requires for all other fisheries.
column2: 南极海洋生命资源保护公约还应该把对磷虾捕捉的这些监督管理措施实施到所有其他也有此要求的渔业上。

column1: Antarctic krill must not be fished to feed the fish farms of the world while starving the penguins, seals, whales, and other species whose survival depends on these tiny, but vitally important, creatures.
column2: 人们不应捕捉南极磷虾去喂养养鱼场的鱼类而让那些依靠这些细小、但却极其重要的动物为生的企鹅、海豹、鲸和其他物种饱受饥饿。

column1: Killing Growth in Russia
column2: 扼杀俄罗斯的经济增长

column1: I want Russia to be a boring country – at least for the next few decades.
column2: 我宁愿俄罗斯变成一个令人乏味的国家，至少在今后的几十年中。

column1: In the twentieth century, Russia set an unquestionable record for all sorts of upheavals and social experiments that attracted the world’s attention.
column2: 二十世纪的俄罗斯创造了一份不容质疑的纪录，包括经历了各种各样的动乱剧变和社会实践，吸引了全世界的关注目光。

column1: A time-out is essential.
column2: 现在该是暂停的时候了。

column1: This objective seemed to be entirely within reach – or at least possible – until the first half of 2003.
column2: 在2003年上半年前，我们似乎还可以不费吹灰之力地达成这个目标，至少很有可能达到。

column1: Foreign correspondents accredited in Moscow complained that nothing was happening in Putin’s Russia.
column2: 受命驻莫斯科的外国记者还曾抱怨普京管理下的俄罗斯波澜不惊，无甚可报道。

column1: Investment in the Russian economy was growing fast.
column2: 俄罗斯的经济投资呈高速发展。

column1: Unfortunately, Russia’s rulers are not accustomed to leaving the country and the rest of the world for long without something surprising to gawk at.
column2: 不幸的是，俄罗斯当权者还未习惯这种状态，隔不了多久他们总要做出些让本国和世界各国目瞪口呆的惊人之举。

column1: Instilling a feeling of insecurity is the best way to scare your population into submission and frighten away potential investors.
column2: 恐吓你的人民使他们屈从听命的最有效方法是逐步灌输安全丧失感，此法同时亦能吓跑潜在投资者。

column1: How democratic or undemocratic a regime is usually doesn't bother investors. All they need and care about is stable, predictable rules.
column2: 通常，困扰投资者的问题不是一个政权民主与否，投资者需要并且在意的，是稳定且可预见的政策。

column1: Indeed, the watchword among major investors is inertia.
column2: 事实上，巨额投资者们都信奉惯性二字。

column1: It takes time to reach a decision on whether or not to invest in a project, and once an investment decision is made, it becomes rather difficult to stop the process quickly.
column2: 一个投资项目需要时间达成共识，而一旦决定作出，要立刻叫停这个项目则更为艰难。

column1: Russia’s government is now doing its best to prove that, while difficult, it is possible to defy the laws of business physics and kill investments that are already in the pipeline.
column2: 俄罗斯政府此刻正竭其全力要证明，即使困难重重，他们也是有可能打破商业常规，扼杀已在进行中的投资项目。

column1: When Mikhail Khodorkovsky and other executives of Yukos, his oil company, were arrested last year, corporations investing or interested in investing in Russia were prepared to interpret the crackdown as an isolated incident brought on by the political agenda of the company and its CEO, who should have known better.
column2: 去年，尤科斯石油公司原首席执行官米卡耶·克多可夫斯基和他公司的其他高层人员被捕，正在俄罗斯进行投资及有意向投资的公司已准备好将此次打击镇压当作一个独立事件来看待，全由该公司及其首席执行官的政治议程所引起，个中缘由应该只有克多可夫斯基才比较清楚。

column1: Never mind that by the second half of 2003, it had become obvious that the government intended to use legal means – in the form of massive tax claims – to destroy the company.
column2: 也难怪，到2003年下半年末，政府准备动用法律手段 — — 以大规模税款申索的方式 — — 以打垮该公司的意图已十分明显。

column1: When only one company faced legal and financial problems, investors who had made a decision to put their money in Russia were ready to ignore this kind of development.
column2: 若仅有一家公司出现法律和经济问题，那些有意向把钱投放在俄罗斯的投资者们往往情愿忽略这一事态的发展。

column1: “This must be an exception,” they kept repeating, like a mantra or a prayer.
column2: “这一定是个例外 ， ” 他们总是这么重复，宛如重复着咒语，又像在祈祷。

column1: I’ve heard something similar when Russian problems are discussed: “Just finish this Yukos affair.
column2: 我也在人们讨论俄罗斯问题时听到过类似的话语 ， “ 快点结束尤科斯的案子吧！

column1: We don’t care how it goes, just put an end to it.”
column2: 我们才不在乎它进行得如何呢，早日了结它吧！

column1: Unfortunately, the genie has been let out of the bottle.
column2: 不幸的是，妖魔一旦出瓶就那难以收回。

column1: Throughout 2004, it became abundantly clear that Russia’s internal security apparatus had gained the upper hand in deciding how to manage economic and political problems.
column2: 2004一整年，比起经济和政治问题的管理，俄罗斯国内的安全设施建设明显占据了上风。

column1: Security structures developed a taste for this kind of work, and welcomed new responsibilities.
column2: 安全机构对这项工作乐此不疲，对新职责颇为欢迎。

column1: In many ways, they began to see fighting big business as akin to fighting terrorists.
column2: 从很多方面来看，他们开始把反巨大型企业与反恐行动一样对待。

column1: And, indeed, they share one thing in common: the fight never ends.
column2: 确实，有一点是共通的：这场战争永无终日。

column1: More and more tax claims are being produced, and not only against Yukos.
column2: 除了针对尤科斯石油公司之外，越来越多的税款申索开始起草。

column1: Tax claims against the telecommunications company Vympelkom (one of Russia’s leading firms, and the first to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange in 90 years) send an unambiguous signal to investors: no one is safe.
column2: 矛头直指Vympelkom电信公司的税款申索（俄罗斯最大的电信运营商，也是过去90年中第一个在纽约证券交易所上市的公司）向所有的投资者发出了一个明确无误的信号：没有谁能够幸免于难。

column1: In fact, official documents have now even started questioning the legitimacy of the privatization of the leading Russian companies in the 1990’s, which has opened the way for discussions about revising the outcomes of these privatizations.
column2: 事实上，官方文件甚至已经开始质疑1990年代俄罗斯大公司私有化的合法性，并启动了有关修正这些私有化成果的讨论。

column1: Similarly, British Petroleum, which has invested more in Russia than any other company to date, has recently discovered that its rights to the Kovytkino gas field are not guaranteed at all. This property, it now seems, could be reclaimed by the state at any moment.
column2: 与此同时，目前为止在俄罗斯境内投资最多的英国石油公司最近已经发现他们在Kovytkino油田的权利已完全得不到保障。

column1: It would be wrong to draw long-term conclusions from short-term economic information, even if this information confirms reality.
column2: 要从短期经济信息中得出长期结论是种错误做法，即使这些信息应证了事实。

column1: The alarming tendencies we are seeing today may be short-lived and with no serious consequences.
column2: 今日我们目睹的趋势令人担忧，但也可能是短暂无常且不会造成严重后果的。

column1: Post-socialist growth is a process that cannot (and should not) be easily stopped.
column2: 后社会主义的急速增长已经难以（也不该）止步。

column1: If, however, the authorities continue their efforts to destabilize the Russian economy, today’s disturbing tendencies may actually take root.
column2: 然而，如果政府继续不遗余力地破坏俄罗斯经济，那么目前这种令人担忧的趋势将会扎根于俄罗斯。

column1: Russia can then forget about attaining the fast, sustainable growth that China has achieved. Instead, we Russians will find ourselves trying to avert an impending economic crisis.
column2: 到彼时，俄罗斯就该彻底忘掉中国所取得的快速持续的经济增长，取而代之是发现自己正在全力避免一场日益迫近的经济危机。

column1: Of course, no one can predict when such a crisis might occur.
column2: 当然，没有人可以预见这场危机何时发生。

column1: But one thing is certain: we will know which path the country’s leaders have chosen sooner rather than later.
column2: 但是有一点却是肯定的：我们迟早会知道国家领导人究竟选择了哪条路。

column1: Indeed, this year could be Russia’s most fateful yet.
column2: 毫无疑问，今年将会是俄罗斯最至关重大的一年。

column1: Killing the Death Penalty
column2: 废除死刑

column1: It is finally happening.
column2: 人们终于等来了这一时刻。

column1: After 13 years of negotiations, delays, and hesitation, the UN General Assembly will vote this month on the proposal for a universal moratorium on the death penalty.
column2: 经过13年的谈判、推迟以及犹豫，联合国大会将在本月对一项全面暂停死刑提议进行投票。

column1: A large majority of the UN adopted the proposal on 15 November, despite attempts by some member states to obstruct, amend, or bury it.
column2: 联合国的大多数成员国不顾某些国家的阻挠、修正或者终结的企图在11月15日通过了这一提议。

column1: Fortunately, in the end, the opponents were forced to fight a will stronger than their own: the will of those who – after the abolition of slavery and torture – want to mark another turning point for civilization.
column2: 所幸的是，最终，反对国家被迫与一个比它们自己的更为强烈的意志斗争，也就是，在废除了奴隶制和酷刑后，想要在文明的道路上做出另一个转折点的人们的意志。

column1: But will this December’s vote be a mere formality?
column2: 但是，今年12月的投票仅仅是例行公事吗？

column1: Experience teaches us to be prudent.
column2: 经验告诉告诉我们要谨慎。

column1: I have not opened my bottle of spumante yet.
column2: 我现在还没有开酒庆贺。

column1: To be honest, I am not sure that all of the world’s governments have accepted the inevitable, or that even the most inflexible will now agree to the moratorium.
column2: 坦率而言，我并不确信世界上所有国家政府都已经接受了这一不可避免的事实，或者即使最为顽固的现在也会同意暂停死刑。

column1: But I continue to have faith that the General Assembly will know, as always, how to meet this challenge.
column2: 但是，联合国大会将会像以往一贯那样面对挑战。 我对此继续保持信念。

column1: We are all aware that even if the vote succeeds, the UN resolution will not be binding, and that establishing and enforcing a moratorium is only a necessary mid-way step toward full abolition.
column2: 我们都知道，即使投票成功，这一联合国决议也没有约束力，而且，确立和执行暂停死刑只是朝向全面废除目标上必要一步。

column1: I believe the UN should push for an immediate de facto suspension, without waiting for the debates to begin on legal reforms in the respective countries.
column2: 我相信，联合国应该不等候有关国家法律改革辩论开始就推动立即在事实上中止死刑。

column1: I hope that this approach will allow a wide consensus in the General Assembly, and that any last minute change of heart will fail.
column2: 我相信这一手段将会在联合国大会形成广泛共识，而且最后时刻的改变主意将不会成功。

column1: One big lesson I learned during the struggle to create the International Criminal Court (ICC), and now during the battle for a moratorium on the death penalty, is that it is often better to aim for a realistic result rather than a perfect one.
column2: 我在建立国际刑事法庭以及现在暂停死刑的奋斗中所学到的一大的教训就是，很多时候退而求其次往往要好一点。

column1: Before the international community established the ICC, there were two ad hoc tribunals – one for the former Yugoslavia and one for Rwanda. Their work paved the way for the ICC.
column2: 国际社会建立国际刑事法庭之前有两个临时法庭，一个用于前南斯拉夫，另一个用于卢旺达。 这两个法庭的工作为国际刑事法庭铺平了道路。

column1: Some European Union countries wanted to push for complete abolition of the death penalty right away.
column2: 某些欧盟国家想要立即推动完全废除死刑。

column1: I understand their position.
column2: 我理解它们的立场。

column1: I would have wanted the same thing myself.
column2: 我原本自己也想要这样。

column1: But had we followed that route, we would most likely have failed.
column2: 但是如果我们按照这样行事，我们极有可能失败。

column1: There is an important lesson in this for the EU at a time when it is seeking to become a global actor: we must reach an internal consensus while always bearing in mind what the external ramifications of our decision might be.
column2: 欧盟正在寻求成为一个全球性力量。 在这一时候，欧盟有一个重要的经验教训，那就是我们必须达成内部一致，同时总是知道我们的决定所可能带来的外部影响。
